author: Odeinoichus
title: Fair Warning, Review Contains Spoilers of Content, Read at Own Risk.
review:
Set #60155 LEGO City Advent Calendar: I have been collecting the LEGO Friends AC since 2014, this year’s LEGO Friends Advent Calendar is one that just looks uninspiring and definitely not worth the full asking price. I may still inevitably get one, depending on if any discounts are offered, but until then let’s take a look at my first LEGO City Advent Calendar offering.

Box

LEGO City Advent Calendar’s aren’t as colorful as LEGO Friends, but this City Box design is still highly enjoyable. Granted you see many of the models being offered on the outside of the box, so you aren’t really surprised by what you’ll find. However compared to a certain competitor’s foray into the Advent Calendar release which I recently experienced the LEGO boxes are ten times sturdier and better designed.

There’s nice imagery on the back as well demonstrating how to enjoy the Advent Calendar experience, and LEGO Santa has a small checklist of other LEGO City sets from this year you may like for your presents.

The box flap/interior detailing shows a nice festive little winter scene with a large window showing off the outside and a half-inside, half-outside floor plan to place all of your 24 gifts. Overall a very nice box design.

Advent Models

We shall begin with the first day as usual and discuss each model as it happens. As this is my first LEGO City Calendar I shall endeavor to be as thorough as possible.

Day1: Here’s a lovely looking red toy train engine, this mini build is very cute. I’ve seen toy train designs in LEGO before and they aren’t often as involved as this one, here the build involves a good fifteen pieces and makes a fairly lengthy looking Minifigure scale toy train, not steam powered, but certainly not a bullet train design either.

Day 2: Well here’s Minifigure number one, snowboarding child, boy or girl, though I suspect it is meant to be a boy. This is a nice looking minifig, he’s got the green winter jacket which is printed on both sides of the torso, short blue legs (which I believe are the same tone and colour as Bart Simpson’s legs), a grey helmet and an orange snowboard complete the look… his face is standard fare from LEGO City.

Putting him next to the toy train from day one we find, that is one big model train, it’s got to be at least advanced model fare. Not much else to say, he’s a great looking first offering and will be perfect for your Winter Village display.

Day 3: Well, well, well, it’s the third day and after playing in the snow for hours our little Snowboarder has the chance to warm himself by the small fireplace built today. This model is very familiar looking, the overall design I feel I’ve seen in past advent calendars, the colours are different, they’re darker in tone compared to a LEGO Friends set.

You get three mason bricks, four sloped bricks, some flame elements, a few bar pieces 1x2 plates with bar parts used for the mantle in pearl gold and three 1x4 plates to help hold everything together. Overall a small fireplace design, however it’s fairly cute, compact and cozy looking. Pretty good offering today.

Day 4: Today you can sit beside your fireplace in a nice red chair with a little lamp and Christmas tree decoration. Comparing this to similar ideas in the LEGO Friends range I have to say this little model is not as detailed as it could be. However it does make for a nice little seating area for Minifigures, and adds further to the cozy, compact nature of the models.

I do wish that the chair was elevated on a 2x4 brick though, the side-table with the lamp and festive tree decoration looks particularly wonky when placed next to the standard red LEGO Chair found in most City vehicles. Even a 2x4 plate would have helped a bit here to make it appear better scaled next to one another. Overall a solid 3 for today’s offering.

Day 5: What’s Christmas without goodies? Today is a tiny LEGO Gingerbread House model, it uses a clever technique by having two of the hinged brick elements with 2x4 hinge plates attached to make the angled roof, festive green and red SNOT studs are used for the icing and for the base a 2x4 plate.

Very festive looking and cute, I suppose our Snowboarder will now have a festive snack before returning to his outdoor activity. 4 out of 5 for today’s model.

Day 6: Time for a slightly more involved build today, it’s a nice cherry red and black model airplane. Micro builds at this scale are always interesting, and at least in the LEGO City Advent Calendar I find they do a much appropriate job compared to the micro ship builds in LEGO Star Wars calendars. Of course that’s just my opinion.

I don’t pretend to know what model of plane this is meant to evoke, I’m not up on makes and models of Airplanes, but I do know it’s a very nifty looking design with swept back wings, a small tail and a clear dish used to simulate the whirling propeller. Overall a very enjoyable build, strong 4 out of 5 for today’s model. Gotta admit though these aren’t entirely to Minifigure scale as I first thought, but they still work as toys for the Minifigure to enjoy.

Day 7: It’s a little sled. This model’s fairly nice, the greatest element here is the hockey stick piece in brown. You only use about seven pieces, this sled isn’t as involved as some of the ones I’ve seen in LEGO Friends, however it works ok for what it’s attempting. Average 3 out of 5 for this model.

Day 8: Hello Minifigure #2, is it Grandma? Or Mrs. Claus in casual Christmas sweater with a tray full of cookies? The front of the box would seem to indicate this, she’s a decent enough offering for the day, and you get five of the printed cookie elements which is always a nice bonus. Very solid 3 out of 5 for today’s offerings too.

Day 9: It’s a Holly Jolly Christmas, whoops, wrong classic song reference. Here’s a very intricately detailed little model with some solid building techniques, what is it? Well it’s a Snowblower, this isn’t often seen in LEGO, in fact this is my first exposure to the push blower design… I like it, what’s even crazier is that it’s got festive red and green colouring.

Here’s our first 5 out of 5, the build is satisfying, the design works quite nicely, the only complaint I’d have is that the image showing how to build it can be a little bit confusing, I’d say it’s a strong offering though and very original for a model in a calendar… at least from my perspective.

Day 10: Ok, this is another out of the ballpark model, at first glance I was confused by it, but once I figured out where every piece went and built it up this is a really impressive looking figure.

What is this model? Well it’s another toy vehicle, I’m tempted to say it’s either a cargo plane or a seaplane, perhaps even the Sea Duck from Tailspin, considering it’s mostly using light orange coloured pieces. This is a really fun model, another solid 5 out of 5 for me and definitely a better offering then some of the past Friends models I’ve had the misfortune of encountering, why can’t the Friends designers give us solid looking toy replicas for the Mini-Dolls to play with? I mean miniature vehicle designs like this are a goldmine.

Day 11: Oh Hum, another day, another Advent Calendar Snowman… These things really do show up a lot and there are very few differences, the lower body using the Astromech dome piece, the same yellow tooth piece used for a scarf… yeah this is a repetitive day.

That being said it’s a solid little model and so I’d give this a 3 out of 5, Snowmen are a staple of Advent Calendars and many different designs have been created so putting them all together for a large display during the holidays is a great idea.

Day 12: I think this is an outdoor Hot Chocolate stand, it includes a red coffee mug and is built into your standard outdoor stall… actually I’m a bit disappointed with this one, it’s not as detailed as the LEGO Friends variety, and features less things to pick up since there’s just the one mug, there’s no dispenser for the Hot Chocolate or any sweets to pick up. In LEGO Friends calendars, when the designers weren’t wasting time, they actually made much better outdoor food stalls for the festive parties that the characters were having.

This does look like something a kid would put together in order to sell Hot Chocolate on the side of the road… why a kid would be doing that during the winter is a huge question in my book, I guess it’s just not something I’ve ever done.

Decent enough model for what you get and perhaps there will be more to incorporate into the play/display scenario tomorrow. 2 out of 5.

Day 13: Guess I was wrong, today is another Minifigure… Interesting to see that there are two female characters in this calendar so far, possibly three if you consider the young snowboarder to be a girl and not a boy.

This is an odd idea though, it’s a Coast Guard worker if the shield on the badge is accurate and she’s skiing. She includes a nice set of teal skis, she’s built out of the standard LEGO City parts with typical prints. I’d give her a 4 out of 5, it’s a nice addition and definitely more impressive from yesterday.

Day 14: Today is another model, or toy if you prefer, and this one is… a cargo container ship. Not exactly Maesrk in colour choice, but it’s a nifty looking model and really works quite nicely. I suspect the yellow, green and red 1x2 bricks are cargo containers loaded with LEGO sets to be delivered on Christmas Eve.

This is a really solid model, I’d give today 5 out of 5, just remember, this model more than likely will not float.

Day 15: I think today is supposed to be a model Firetruck, honestly it took me several minutes to figure it out, the model looked kind of like a Zamboni or something to me at first. Then it dawned on me, the black 1x2 with bars on both ends is meant to be the ladder… boy was that a surprise, a pleasant one as well.

The model is a bit odd in design as it isn’t obvious what it’s meant to be right away, but it’s a fun looking toy and really great. All of these models/toys from this Advent Calendar are extremely impressive with a lot of fun detailing and useful parts. I’d give this a 4 out 5.

Day 16: A toy race car today, this model design is a bit of a weaker one compared to the previous models. I blame the design choice to use two 1x2 plates with clips to make the body, the wheels wind up not being level so it looks a bit wonky.

It is nice to include the small rail cart wheels as you get an extra in the bag. More of a 2 out of 5 today, the lowest score so far, other models for race car toys work much better than this particular design.

Day 17: After yesterday’s disappointing offering this toy/model is world’s better. We get an awesome looking helicopter build today and it’s really satisfying. Ten to twelve pieces are used to make a large helicopter model, this isn’t a tiny little charter number, but a heavy duty coast guard helicopter, considering the parts used include mostly orange and blue coast guard colours. 4 out of 5 today.

Day 18: Coast Guard helicopter yesterday, Coast Guard worker today… actually I’m surprised to see so many Coast Guard themed models and Minifigures here. She’s got a walkie talkie, or perhaps a control device for the model helicopter from yesterday, also the orange Coast Guard uniform is standard here. She’s a solid 4 out of 5 as well.

Day 19: Christmas Tree day, a bit earlier than I’d expect, but a fun looking model and something for all those toys/models to be put around as presents for the LEGO Minifigures to enjoy on Christmas Morning. There isn’t much to say here, it’s build similarly to how we’ve seen small tree models before with the green sloped 1x1 bricks staggered to give the illusion of branches. Another decent model though, 4 out of 5.

Day 20: Only a few days left and here’s our first male Minifigure. He’s holding a power saw and dressed in what I assume is a ranger outfit, so I’m guessing he’s the one who cut down the tree from yesterday to use for the house. He’s got the standard looking Minifigure parts from LEGO City, the baseball style cap on his head in is a nice light tan colour though which I think is a bit rarer. Perhaps this fellow is from the Jungle Sub-Theme, then again he doesn’t have a machete. 3 out of 5 for today.

Day 21: Ah, not a lumberjack then, but an Ice Sculptor yesterday because today is the highlight of the Advent Calendar in my eyes and one of the things I was greatly looking forward to. This is a really great looking Ice Angel sculpture, it uses a lot of clear blue parts, but the best parts are the Legends of Chima fire wings parts in clear blue, which is a rare part and something folks will really want. This is definitely a 5 out of 5 day because of the unique design of the model and the fun parts.

Day 22: It’s a small Snowmobile for today, this is a nice looking model with some decent parts in light orange, the Lion Tribe colours in Legends of Chima. It’s not a bad little model, I’d give it a 3 out of 5, a solid looking Snowmobile that any of the Minifigures can ride.

Day 23: What will be the second to last day of this Advent Calendar? Well, today is another small sled, this one designed to attach to the back of yesterday’s Snowmobile and can be used to transport presents or another Minifigure for a fun time playing in the snow. This one is red with a pearl gold 1x2 plate with bar attachment on the back for festive detailing… I’d give this model by itself 3 out of 5, but the two combined together get a solid 5 out of 5 because of the versatility and playability factor.

Day 24: He’s always out and about on Christmas Eve and so, much like I suspect ever LEGO City Advent Calendar ends today is none other than Santa Claus. Ever since Series 8 of the CMF Santa has pretty much looked the same, the parts are always the same, same red top, same red pants, same little white beard and same Santa cap head piece. The facial print on him might have been tweaked here and there to make him look more like the Jolly Old St. Nick image, however there’s really nothing that’s different… In fact I think this is the exact same Minifigure that was used in the Holiday Vignette sets from 2015. Overall though he’s still a solid Minifigure, and if you want a LEGO City diorama all decked out for the holidays you’ll need a Santa on every corner. 3 out of 5 for the final door.

Overall opinion

LEGO Advent Calendars are always impressive, this being my first offering from LEGO City I would have to say it’s a pretty decent looking package overall, I would strongly suggest trying to get it from Costco though, I found it in Canada at Costco for 29.99$ which is a much better asking price for what is being offered here.

I’m actually liking the look of this year’s LEGO City Calendar compared to the LEGO Friends calendar from this year, which is why I picked it up first for a change. All of the models that represent toy vehicles are extremely impressive, with exception to the penny racer style race car, and there’s some really great festive looking models. The Ice Angel is a great model with some truly fascinating parts and so I would strongly recommend this year’s LEGO City Advent Calendar.

author: weirdbricks
title: The weakest city calendar in years!
review:
Lego is running out of ideas...

So we all know that lego is running out of ideas. But the calendars shouldn't be affected by that. For the past three years, both city and star-wars calendars have been weaker and weaker. This calendar is a pretty good example for what a calendar should NOT look like. My favorite of the city calendars might be the 2009 or 2013 one, due to the nice variety of builds and figures. Hope you enjoy my review!

Minifigures:

In this calendar we only get 6 minifigures, compared to many of the others where we got between 8 and 10. There are no exclusive figures here. Figures included: Kid on a snowboard, Grandma, Jungle explorer, Coast guard woman, Coast guard woman on ski and at last the Santa Claus. None of these figures are in a certain grade exclusive or special. Here i wished they could include more figures and might give us an exclusive Santa. In my subjective opinion, i do like the grandma the most, due to her torso print. 

Other minibuilds:

Well... This selection of minibuilds is just so bad, that it almost makes me cry. Look at the Christmas tree. How it developed from a tall good-looking build in 2009 to a small ugly part-thingy today. The Christmas trees is just getting worse and worse. We also got a snowman! So freakin cool... (not)! The snowman looks terrible. Not impressive at all. The rest of the minibuilds is just disappointing and terrible. 

Overall rating:

Well. It's not much positive to say about this calendar. The calendars both city, star wars, and in certain grade friends, is just getting poorer and poorer for each year. The PPP for the calendar is not great, but acceptable. It can't have taken longer time than a few hours to make this calendar. Very disappointed! In total rating i would give it 3/6. I would not pay mre than 20$ fot this!

Thanks for reading!
